content: The "Girl Scouts USA Centennial Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the Girl Scouts as a leading organization for girls, founded in 1912 by Juliette Gordon Low with the help of Sir Robert Baden-Powell. Juliette Gordon Low dedicated 15 years to building the organization, which became the largest voluntary association for women and girls in the United States. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America was chartered by the United States Congress in 1950 and has over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. They are part of a global organization with 10 million members in 145 countries, inspiring millions of American women through Girl Scouting. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America, chartered by Congress in 1950, has over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. Celebrating its 100th Anniversary on March 12, 2012, the organization will have $1 silver coins minted in commemoration, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted for the centennial of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America will include a value designation, the year 2013, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Girl Scouts and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The coins minted for the centennial of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike these coins, with preference for the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue these coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2013, and they will be sold at a price equal to their face value. The Secretary will sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All coin sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. The Secretary will pay all surcharges from coin sales to the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Girl Scouts' expenditures. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for the coin program issuance limitation. Technical amendments allow the continued issuance of commemorative coins minted in 2009. Surcharges from coin sales will be distributed to specified organizations. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for the coin program issuance limitation. Surcharges from coin sales will be distributed to specified organizations in specific proportions for designated purposes.
